\typeout{Chapter 6 Radians}
\typeout{************************************************}
%
\begin{chapterptx}{Chapter}{Radians}{}{Radians}{}{}{chapter-chap6}
\renewcommand*{\chaptername}{Chapter}
\begin{introduction}{}%
\begin{sidebyside}{2}{0}{0}{0}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.6}[center]%
%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}\(\displaystyle \blert{\textbf{Arclength and Radians}}\)%
\item{}\(\displaystyle \blert{\textbf{Circular Functions}}\)%
\item{}\(\displaystyle \blert{\textbf{Graphs of the Circular Functions}}\)%
\end{itemize}
%
\end{sbspanel}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.4}[center]%
\includegraphics[width=\linewidth]{external/photos/ch6-1.png}
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
\par
Have you ever wonderd why we divide the circle into 360 degrees?  Nobody really knows the answer, but it may well have started around 600 BCE with the Babylonians.%
\begin{sidebyside}{2}{0}{0}{0.1}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.6}[center]%
The Babylonians lived between the Tigris and Euphrates rivers in present day Turkey and Syria.  They kept written records using a stylus to press cuneiform, or wedge-shaped, symbols into wet clay tablets, which were then baked in the sun. Thousands of these tablets have survived and give us detailed information about the mathematical practices of the time.%
\par
The Babylonians used a base 60 number system because the number 60 has many factors. They did not invent decimal fractions, so they found it difficult to deal with remainders when doing division.  But 60 can be divided evenly by 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6, which made calculations with common fractions much easier.%
\end{sbspanel}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.3}[center]%
\includegraphics[width=\linewidth]{external/photos/ch6-2.png}
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
\par
We still see traces of their base 60 system in our own day:  there are 60 seconds in a minute, and 60 minutes in an hour.%
\begin{sidebyside}{2}{0}{0}{0.1}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.6}%
In geometry, Babylonian mathematicians used the corner of an equilateral triangle as their basic unit of angular measure, and naturally divided that angle into 60 smaller angles.  Now, if the corners of six equilateral triangles are placed together they form a complete circle, and that is why there are six times 60, or 360 degrees of arc in a circle.%
\end{sbspanel}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.3}%
\includegraphics[width=\linewidth]{external/photos/ch6-3.png}
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
\par
During the reign of Nebuchadnezzar, using the tools and technology available to them, Babylonian astronomers calculated that a complete year numbered 360 days.  This made dividing the circle into 360 degrees even more useful.%
\par
So the number 360 is not fundamental to the nature of a circle.  If ancient civilizations had defined the full circle to be some other number of degrees, we'd probably be using that number today.%
\par
But why do we need another, different way to measure angles?  In this chapter we'll study \terminology{radian measure}\index{radian}, which at first may seem awkward and unnatural.  As a hint, consider that although 360 is not fundamental to circles, the number \(\alert{\pi}\) is.%

\begin{sbspanel}{0.45}[center]%
Imagine a circle of radius 1unit rolling along a straight line. The circumference of a circle is \(2\pi\) times the length of its radius, so when the circle has turned through one complete revolution, it has traveled a distance of \(2\pi\) units.  When the circle has turned through half a revolution, it has taveled a distance of \(\pi\) units.%
\par
In radian measure, the angle through which the circle has turned is equal to the distance the circle has traveled, or the length of the arc that has unrolled on the line.%
\par
The idea of radian measure was developed by Roger Cotes, an English mathematician who worked closely with Isaac Newton.  He described the radian in everything but name, and recognized its naturalness as a unit of angular measure.%
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
\par
The term \terminology{radian}\index{radian} first appeared in print on June 5, 1873, on an exam written by James Thomson, the brother of Lord Kelvin, at Queen's College in Belfast.%
\par
In calculus and most other branches of mathematics beyond practical geometry, angles are nearly always measured in radians. Because radians arise naturally when dealing with circles, important relationships are expressed more concisely in radians. In particular, results involving trigonometric functions are simpler when the variables are expressed in radians.%
\end{introduction}%

\typeout{Section 6.1 Arclength and Radians}

\begin{sectionptx}{Section}{Arclength and Radians}{}{Arclength and Radians}{}{}{section-Arclength-and-Radians}
\index{arclength}%
\index{radian}%
\begin{introduction}{}%
\begin{sidebyside}{2}{0}{0.05}{0.02}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.55}[center]%
Imagine that you are riding on a Ferris wheel of radius 100 feet, and each rotation takes eight minutes.  We can use angles in standard position to describe your location as you travel around the wheel. The figure at right shows the locations indicated by \(\theta = 0\degree,~ 90\degree,~ 180\degree,\) and  \(270\degree\).  But degrees are not the only way to specify location on a circle.%
\end{sbspanel}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.38}[center]%
\resizebox{\linewidth}{!}{%
\begin{tikzpicture}[scale=.7]

\coordinate (O) at (0,0);
\draw[blue,thick] (O) circle (1.5cm);
\coordinate (A) at (0:1.5);
\coordinate (B) at (90:1.5);
\coordinate (C) at (180:1.5);
\coordinate (D) at (270:1.5);

\draw[black,thick] (-1.7,0)--(1.7,0);
\draw[black,thick] (0,-1.7)--(0,1.7);

\filldraw[red] (A) circle (2.pt) node[anchor=west, align=left, yshift=-.2cm,scale=.8] {\color{blue}$\theta=0\degree$ \\ \color{blue}$p=0$ \\ \color{blue}$t=0$};
\filldraw[red] (B) circle (2.pt) node[anchor=south west, align=left,scale=.8] {\color{blue}$\theta=90\degree$ \\ \color{blue}$p=25$ \\ \color{blue}$t=2$};
\filldraw[red] (C) circle (2.pt) node[anchor=east, align=left, yshift=-.2cm,scale=.8] {\color{blue}$\theta=180\degree$ \\ \color{blue}$p=50$ \\ \color{blue}$t=4$};
\filldraw[red] (D) circle (2.pt) node[anchor=north west, align=left, yshift=-2, scale=.8] {\color{blue}$\theta=270\degree$ \\ \color{blue}$p=75$ \\ \color{blue}$t=6$};
    \end{tikzpicture}
}%
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
\par
We could use percent of one complete rotation and label the same locations by \(p = 0,~ p = 25,~ p = 50,~\text{and}~ p = 75\). Or we could use the time elapsed, so that for this example we would have \(t = 0,~ t = 2,~t = 4,~\text{and}~ t = 6\) minutes.%
\par
Another useful method to describe your location uses the distance traveled, or \terminology{arclength}, along the circle.  How far have you traveled around the Ferris wheel at each of the locations shown?%
\par
Before we consider that question, let's agree on some vocabulary. An \terminology{arc} is a portion of a circle, and its length, quite naturally, is called \terminology{arclength}. An angle with vertex at the center of the circle is called a \terminology{central angle}, and a central angle whose sides meet the endpoints of an arc is said to \terminology{subtend} the arc. Or we may say that the angle \terminology{spans} the arc. If the arc represents a distance traveled, we sometimes refer to such an angle as the \terminology{angle of displacement}.%
\end{introduction}%

%
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection  Arclength}
\typeout{************************************************}
%
\begin{subsectionptx}{Subsection}{Arclength}{}{Arclength}{}{}{subsection-Arclength-and-Radians-e}
\index{arclength}%
Recall that the circumference of a circle is proportional to its radius,%
\begin{equation*}
\blert{C = 2 \pi r}
\end{equation*}
If we walk around the entire circumference of a circle, the distance we travel is \(2\pi\) times the length of the radius, or about 6.28 times the radius. If we walk only part of the way around the circle, then the distance we travel depends also on the angle of displacement.%
\begin{sidebyside}{2}{0}{0.05}{0.08}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.45}%
For example, an angle of \(45\degree\) is \(\dfrac{1}{8}\) of a complete revolution, so the the length of the arc from point \(A\) to point \(B\), called \(s\) in the figure at right, is \(\dfrac{1}{8}\) of the circumference. Thus%
\end{sbspanel}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.42}%
\resizebox{\linewidth}{!}{%
\begin{tikzpicture}

\coordinate (O) at (0,0);
\draw[gray!90!white,thick] (O) circle (1.5cm);
\coordinate (A) at (0:1.5);
\coordinate (B) at (45:1.5);

\draw[black,thick] (-1.7,0)--(1.7,0);
\draw[black,thick] (0,-1.7)--(0,1.7);
\draw[gray, thick] (O)--(B);


\draw[red,thick,->,>=stealth'](0.4,0) arc(0:45:.4) node[right, midway, yshift=3]{ $\frac{1}{8}$ rev};
\draw[blue, ultra thick](1.5,0) arc(0:45:1.5) node[right, midway, color=blue, text width=2.5cm, xshift=3] { $s=\frac{\pi}{4}r$ (or $\frac{1}{8}$ circumference)};
\filldraw[red] (A) circle (2.pt) node[anchor=north west] {$A$};
\filldraw[red] (B) circle (2.pt) node[anchor=south, xshift=4] {$B$};
    \end{tikzpicture}
}%
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
\par
%
\begin{equation*}
s = \dfrac{1}{8}(2\pi r) = \dfrac{\pi}{4} r
\end{equation*}
%
\begin{sidebyside}{2}{0}{0.05}{0.05}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.45}%
Similarly, the angle of displacement from point \(A\) to point \(C\) is \(\dfrac{3}{4}\) of a complete revolution, so the arclength \(s\) along the circle from \(A\) to \(C\), shown at right, is%
\end{sbspanel}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.45}%
\resizebox{\linewidth}{!}{%
\begin{tikzpicture} 

\coordinate (O) at (0,0);
\draw[gray!90!white,thick] (O) circle (1.5cm);
\coordinate (A) at (0:1.5);
\coordinate (C) at (270:1.5);

\draw[black,thick] (-1.7,0)--(1.7,0);
\draw[black,thick] (0,-1.7)--(0,1.7);
\draw[gray, thick] (O)--(C);


\draw[red,thick,->,>=stealth'](0.3,0) arc(0:270:.3) node[above left, midway, xshift=6, yshift=-5]{\small $\frac{3}{4}$ rev};
\draw[blue, ultra thick](1.5,0) arc(0:270:1.5) node[left, midway, xshift=-.55cm, yshift=-1.1cm, align=right, text width=2.5cm, color=blue]{$s=\frac{3\pi}{2}r$  (or $\frac{3}{4}$ circumference)};
\filldraw[red] (A) circle (2.pt) node[anchor=north west] {$A$};
\filldraw[red] (C) circle (2.pt) node[anchor=north east] {$C$};
    \end{tikzpicture}
}%
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
\par
%
\begin{equation*}
s = \dfrac{3}{4}(2\pi r) = \dfrac{3\pi}{2} r
\end{equation*}
%
\par
In general, for a given circle the length of the arc spanned by an angle is proportional to the size of the angle.%
\begin{assemblage}{Assemblage}{Arclength on a Circle.}{assemblage-Arclength-and-Radians-e-i}%
%
\begin{equation*}
\blert{\textbf{Arclength}}~ = ~ \blert{(\textbf{fraction of one revolution}) \cdot (2\pi r)}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{assemblage}
The Ferris wheel in the introduction has circumference%
\begin{equation*}
C = 2\pi (100) = 628~ \text{feet}
\end{equation*}
so in half a revolution you travel 314 feet around the edge, and in one-quarter revolution you travel 157 feet.%
\begin{sidebyside}{2}{0}{0.1}{0.03}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.55}%
To indicate the same four locations on the wheel by distance traveled, we would use%
\begin{equation*}
s = 0,~ s = 157,~ s = 314,~ \text{and}~ s = 471\text{,}
\end{equation*}
as shown at right.%
\end{sbspanel}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.32}%
\resizebox{\linewidth}{!}{%
\begin{tikzpicture}[scale=.72]

\coordinate (O) at (0,0);

\coordinate (C) at (180:1.5);
\coordinate (D) at (270:1.5);

\filldraw[red] (D) circle (2.pt) node[anchor=north west, align=left, yshift=-2, text=blue] {$s=471$};

\begin{example}{Example}{}{example-Arclength-and-Radians-e-l}%
What length of arc is spanned by an angle of \(120\degree\) on a circle of radius 12 centimeters?%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{\blocktitlefont Solution}.\hypertarget{solution-Arclength-and-Radians-e-l-b}{}\quad{}Because \(\dfrac{120}{360} = \dfrac{1}{3}\), an angle of \(120\degree\) is \(\dfrac{1}{3}\) of a complete revolution, as shown at right.%
\begin{sidebyside}{2}{0}{0}{0}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.68}%
Using the formula above with \(r = 12\), we find that%
\begin{equation*}
s = \dfrac{1}{3}(2\pi \cdot 12) = \dfrac{2 \pi}{3} \cdot 12 = 8\pi ~ \text{cm}
\end{equation*}
or about 25.1 cm.%
\end{sbspanel}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.32}%
\resizebox{\linewidth}{!}{%
\begin{tikzpicture}[scale=.8]

\draw[black,thick] (0,-1.7)--(0,1.7);
\draw[gray, thick] (O)--(B);

\filldraw[blue] (A) circle (2.pt);
\filldraw[blue] (B) circle (2.pt);

\draw[red,thick,->,>=stealth'](0.3,0) arc(0:120:.3) node[above right, midway, xshift=2, yshift=-5]{ $120\degree$};
\draw[blue, ultra thick](1.5,0) arc(0:120:1.5) node[above right, midway, xshift=.0cm, yshift=-.1cm]{$s=8\pi$ cm};
\node[text=blue, fill=white, inner sep=1pt] at (0,-.6){ $r=12$ cm};
    \end{tikzpicture}
}%
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
\end{example}
\begin{inlineexercise}{Checkpoint}{}{exercise-Arclength-and-Radians-e-m}%
How far have you traveled around the edge of a Ferris wheel of radius 100 feet when you have turned through an angle of \(150\degree\)?%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{\blocktitlefont Answer}.\hypertarget{answer-Arclength-and-Radians-e-m-b}{}\quad{}\(261.8\) ft%
\end{inlineexercise}%
\end{subsectionptx}

\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection  Measuring Angles in Radians}
\typeout{************************************************}

\begin{subsectionptx}{Subsection}{Measuring Angles in Radians}{}{Measuring Angles in Radians}{}{}{subsection-Arclength-and-Radians-f}
\index{radian}%
\index{angle!in radians}%
\index{angle!in radians|seealso{radian}}%
If you think about measuring arclength, you will see that the degree measure of the spanning angle is not as important as the fraction of one revolution it covers. This observation suggests a new unit of measurement for angles, one that is better suited to calculations involving arclength. We'll make one change in our formula for arclength, from%
\begin{equation*}
\textbf{Arclength}~ = ~ (\textbf{fraction of one revolution}) \cdot (2\pi r)
\end{equation*}
to%
\begin{equation*}
\blert{\textbf{Arclength}~ =} ~ \blert{(\textbf{fraction of one revolution}\times 2\pi) \cdot r}
\end{equation*}
We'll call the quantity in parentheses, (fraction of one revolution \(\times 2\pi\)), the \terminology{radian measure} of the angle that spans the arc.%
\begin{assemblage}{Assemblage}{Radians.}{assemblage-Arclength-and-Radians-f-f}%
The \terminology{radian measure} of an angle is given by%
\begin{equation*}
\blert{(\textbf{fraction of one revolution}\times 2\pi)}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{assemblage}
For example, one complete revolution, or \(360\degree\), is equal to \(2\pi\) radians, and one-quarter revolution, or \(90\degree\), is equal to \(\dfrac{1}{4}(2\pi)\) or \(\dfrac{\pi}{2}\) radians. The figure below shows the radian measure of the quadrantal angles.%

\begin{example}{Example}{}{example-Arclength-and-Radians-f-i}%
What is the radian measure of an angle of \(120\degree\)?%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{\blocktitlefont Solution}.\hypertarget{solution-Arclength-and-Radians-f-i-b}{}\quad{}An angle of \(120\degree\) is \(\dfrac{1}{3}\) of a complete revolution, as we saw in the previous example.  Thus, an angle of \(120\degree\) has a radian measure of \(\dfrac{1}{3}(2\pi)\), or  \(\dfrac{2\pi}{3}\).%
\end{example}
\begin{inlineexercise}{Checkpoint}{}{exercise-Arclength-and-Radians-f-j}%
What fraction of a revolution is \(\pi\) radians?  How many degrees is that?%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{\blocktitlefont Answer}.\hypertarget{answer-Arclength-and-Radians-f-j-b}{}\quad{}Half a revolution, \(180\degree\)%
\end{inlineexercise}%
Radian measure does not have to be expressed in multiples of \(\pi\). Remember that \(\pi \approx 3.14\), so one complete revolution is about 6.28 radians, and one-quarter revolution is \(\dfrac{1}{4}(2\pi) = \dfrac{\pi}{2}\), or about 1.57 radians. The figure below shows decimal approximations for the quadrantal angles.%

\begin{note}{Note}{}{note-Arclength-and-Radians-f-m}%
Because they are "benchmarks" for comparing angles, you should be very familiar with both the exact values of these angles in radians and their approximations!%
\end{note}
\begin{example}{Example}{}{example-Arclength-and-Radians-f-n}%
In which quadrant would you find an angle of 2 radians?  An angle of 5 radians?%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{\blocktitlefont Solution}.\hypertarget{solution-Arclength-and-Radians-f-n-b}{}\quad{}Look at the figure above. The second quadrant includes angles between \(\dfrac{\pi}{2}\) and \(\pi\), or 1.57 and 3.14 radians, so 2 radians lies in the second quadrant. An angle of 5 radians is between 4.71 and 6.28, or between \(\dfrac{3\pi}{2}\) and \(2\pi\) radians, so it lies in the fourth quadrant.%
\end{example}

It turns out that measuring angles in radians is useful for many applications besides calculating arclengths, so we need to start thinking in radians. To help that process, we'll first learn to convert between degrees and radians.%
\end{subsectionptx}
%
%
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection  Converting Between Degrees and Radians}
\typeout{************************************************}
%
\begin{subsectionptx}{Subsection}{Converting Between Degrees and Radians}{}{Converting Between Degrees and Radians}{}{}{subsection-Arclength-and-Radians-g}
It is not difficult to convert the measure of an angle in degrees to its measure in radians, or vice versa.  One complete revolution is equal to \(2\pi\) radians or to \(360\degree\), so%
\begin{equation*}
360\degree = 2\pi ~\text{radians}
\end{equation*}
If we divide both sides of this equation by \(360\degree\), we get a fraction that is equal to 1:%
\begin{equation*}
1 = \dfrac{2\pi ~\text{radians}}{360\degree} = \dfrac{\pi ~\text{radians}}{180\degree}
\end{equation*}
And of course it is also true that%
\begin{equation*}
1 = \dfrac{180\degree}{\pi ~\text{radians}}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
Because multiplying by 1 does not change the value of a number, we can use these fractions to convert between degrees and radians.%
\begin{assemblage}{Assemblage}{Converting between degrees and radians.}{assemblage-Arclength-and-Radians-g-d}%
%
\begin{itemize}[label=\textbullet]
\item{}To convert from radians to degrees we multiply the radian measure by \(\dfrac{180\degree}{\pi ~\text{radians}}\).%
\item{}To convert from degrees to radians we multiply the degree measure by \(\dfrac{\pi ~\text{radians}}{180 \degree}\).%
\end{itemize}
%
\end{assemblage}
\begin{example}{Example}{}{example-Arclength-and-Radians-g-e}%
%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*]
\item{}Convert 3 radians to degrees.%
\item{}Convert 3 degrees to radians.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{\blocktitlefont Solution}.\hypertarget{solution-Arclength-and-Radians-g-e-b}{}\quad{}%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*]
\item{}\(\displaystyle (3 ~\text{radians}) \times \left(\dfrac{180\degree}{\pi}\right) = \dfrac{540\degree}{\pi} \approx 171.9\degree\)%
\item{}\(\displaystyle (3\degree) \times \left(\dfrac{\pi}{180\degree}\right) = \dfrac{\pi}{60}\approx 0.05~ \text{radians.}\)%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\begin{inlineexercise}{Checkpoint}{}{exercise-Arclength-and-Radians-g-f}%
%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*]
\item{}Convert \(60\degree\) to radians. Give both an exact answer and an approximation to three decimal places.%
\item{}Convert \(\dfrac{3\pi}{4}\) radians to degrees.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{\blocktitlefont Answer}.\hypertarget{answer-Arclength-and-Radians-g-f-b}{}\quad{}%
\begin{multicols}{2}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*]
\item{}\(\dfrac{\pi}{3} \approx 1.047\) radians%
\item{}\(\displaystyle 135\degree\)%
\end{enumerate}
\end{multicols}
%
\end{inlineexercise}%
Thus, the fraction \(\dfrac{180\degree}{\pi}\) (or its reciprocal \(\dfrac{\pi}{180 \degree}\)) gives us a \emph{conversion factor} between degrees and radians:%
\begin{assemblage}{Assemblage}{Unit Conversion for Angles.}{assemblage-Arclength-and-Radians-g-h}%
%
\begin{equation*}
\blert{\dfrac{180\degree}{\pi~\text{radians}} = 1}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{assemblage}
\begin{note}{Note}{}{note-Arclength-and-Radians-g-i}%
You can review the use of conversion factors in the Algebra Refresher at the end of this Section.%
\end{note}
\begin{sidebyside}{2}{0}{0}{0}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.65}[center]%
From our conversion factor we also learn that%
\begin{equation*}
\blert{ 1~\text{radian} = \dfrac{180\degree}{\pi} \approx 57.3\degree}
\end{equation*}
So while \(1\degree\) is a relatively small angle, 1 radian is much larger — nearly \(60\degree\), in fact.%
\end{sbspanel}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.35}[center]%
\resizebox{\linewidth}{!}{%
\begin{tikzpicture}
\coordinate (O) at (0,0);
\draw[gray!90!white,thick] (O) circle (1.5cm);
\coordinate (A) at (0:1.5);
\coordinate (B) at ($({deg(1)}:1.5) $);
\draw[black,thick] (-1.7,0)--(1.7,0);
\draw[black,thick] (0,-1.7)--(0,1.7);
\draw[blue,thick] (O)--(B);
\draw[red, fill=red] (A) circle (1.5pt);
\draw[red, thick, ->,>=stealth'] (0.4,0) arc ((0:{deg(1)}:0.4) ;
\draw[red, fill=red] (B) circle (1.5pt);
\draw[red, ultra thick] (A) arc ((0:{deg(1)}:1.5) node[right, midway, text=blue] {1 rad$\approx 57.3\degree$};
\end{tikzpicture}
}%
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
\par
But this is reasonable, because there are only a little more than 6 radians in an entire revolution. An angle of 1 radian is shown above.%
\par
We'll soon see that, for many applications, it is easier to work entirely in radians. For reference, the figure below shows a radian protractor.%

\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection  Arclength Formula}
\typeout{************************************************}
%
\begin{subsectionptx}{Subsection}{Arclength Formula}{}{Arclength Formula}{}{}{subsection-Arclength-and-Radians-h}
\index{arclength!formula}%
Now let us return to our calculation of arclength, and we'll see the first instance in which measuring angles in radians is useful: To calculate an arclength we need only multiply the radius of the circle by the radian measure of the spanning angle, \(\theta\). Look again at our formula for arclength:%
\begin{equation*}
\blert{\textbf{Arclength}~ =} ~ \blert{(\textbf{fraction of one revolution}\times 2\pi) \cdot r}
\end{equation*}
%
\par
The quantity in parentheses, fraction of one revolution \(\times 2\pi\), is just the measure of the spanning angle in radians.  Thus, if \(\theta\) is measured in radians, we have the following simple formula for arclength, \(s\).%
\begin{assemblage}{Assemblage}{Arclength Formula.}{assemblage-Arclength-and-Radians-h-e}%
On a circle of radius \(r\), the \terminology{length \(s\) of an arc} spanned by an angle \(\theta\) in radians is%
\begin{equation*}
\blert{s = r\theta}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{assemblage}
\begin{sidebyside}{2}{0}{0}{0}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.55}[center]%
Thus, there is a special relationship between arclength and radians. An angle of 1 radian spans an arc on a circle equal to the radius of the circle, as shown at right. And the length of any arc is just the measure of its spanning angle in radians times the radius of the circle.%
\end{sbspanel}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.45}[center]%
\resizebox{\linewidth}{!}{%
    \begin{tikzpicture}[scale=.7]

    \coordinate (O) at (0,0);
    \draw[gray!90!white,thick] (O) circle (1.cm);
    \draw[gray!90!white,thick] (O) circle (2cm);
    \draw[gray!90!white,thick] (O) circle (4cm);
    \coordinate (A) at (0:1.);
    \coordinate (B) at ($({deg(1)}:4.5) $);
    \coordinate (Ab) at ($(0:2) $);
    \coordinate (Ac) at ($(0:4) $);

    \draw[black,thick] (-4.2,0)--(4.2,0);
    \draw[black,thick] (0,-4.2)--(0,4.2);
    \draw[blue,thick] (O)--(B) node[anchor=south west, xshift=-1, yshift=-2, text=red]{1 rad};
    \draw[red, fill=red] (A) circle (1.5pt) node[anchor=north west, scale=.9, text=black]{1};
    \draw[red, fill=red] ($({deg(1)}:1) $) circle (1.5pt);
    \draw[red, ultra thick] (A) arc ((0:{deg(1)}:1) node[right, midway, xshift=-2, yshift=2, scale=.85, text=blue, scale=.8] {$s=1$};

    \draw[red, fill=red] (Ab) circle (1.5pt) node[anchor=north west, scale=.9, text=black]{2};
    \draw[red, fill=red] ($({deg(1)}:2) $) circle (1.5pt);
    \draw[red, ultra thick] (Ab) arc ((0:{deg(1)}:2) node[right, midway, text=blue] {$s=2$};

    \draw[red, fill=red] (Ac) circle (1.5pt) node[anchor=north west, scale=.9, text=black]{4};
    \draw[red, fill=red] ($({deg(1)}:4) $) circle (1.5pt);
    \draw[red, ultra thick] (Ac) arc ((0:{deg(1)}:4) node[right, midway, text=blue] {$s=4$};
        \end{tikzpicture}
}%
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
\begin{sidebyside}{2}{0}{0.1}{0.08}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.6}[center]%
So for instance, we can use the formula to find the arclength spanned by an angle of 2.5 radians on a circle of radius six inches:%
\begin{equation*}
s = r \theta = 6 (2.5) = 15 ~ \text{inches}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{sbspanel}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.22}[center]%
\resizebox{\linewidth}{!}{%
        \begin{tikzpicture}[scale=0.6]
    
        \coordinate (O) at (0,0);
        \draw[black,thick] (O) circle (2.5cm);
        \coordinate (B) at ($({deg(2.5)}:2.5) $);
    
%       \draw[black,thick] (-2.8,0)--(2.8,0);
%       \draw[black,thick] (0,-2.8)--(0,2.8);
        \draw[gray,thick, dashed] (O)--(B);
    
        \draw[gray, thick, ->, >=stealth'] ({deg(1.3)}:2.9) arc ({deg(1.3)}:{deg(2.5)}:2.9);
        \draw[gray, thick, <-, >=stealth'] (2.9,0) arc (0:deg(1.05):2.9);
        \draw[blue, thick, <->, >=stealth'] (2.5,0) arc (0:deg(2.5):2.5) node[midway, xshift=6, yshift=6] {$s$};
        \draw[red, <->, >=stealth'] (.6,0) arc (0:deg(2.5):.6) node[midway, xshift=7, yshift=6] {2.5 radians};
        \draw[blue,thick] (O)--(2.5,0) node[midway, xshift=0, yshift=-6] {$r = 6$ in};
        \end{tikzpicture}
}%
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
\par
We can also use the formula in the form  \(\theta = \dfrac{s}{r}\) to find an angle that spans a given arc. For example, an arclength equal to one radius determines a central angle of one radian, or about \(57.3\degree\). In the next example, we compute a change in latitude on the Earth's surface.%
\begin{example}{Example}{}{example-Arclength-and-Radians-h-i}%
The radius of the Earth is about 3960 miles. If you travel 500 miles due north, how many degrees of latitude will you traverse? (Latitude is measured in degrees north or south of the equator.)%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{\blocktitlefont Solution}.\hypertarget{solution-Arclength-and-Radians-h-i-b}{}\quad{}\begin{sidebyside}{2}{0}{0.05}{0.05}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.55}[center]%
We think of the distance 500 miles as an arclength on the surface of the Earth, as shown at right. Substituting \(s = 500\) and \(r = 3960\) into the arclength formula gives%
\begin{align*}
500 \amp = 3960 ~ \theta\\
\theta \amp = \dfrac{500}{3960} = 0.1263~ \text{radians}
\end{align*}
%
\end{sbspanel}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.35}[center]%
\resizebox{\linewidth}{!}{%
\begin{tikzpicture}
\coordinate (O) at (0,0);
\draw[gray, thick] (O) circle (1.5cm);

\coordinate (A) at (26:1.5);
\coordinate (B) at (40:1.5);

\draw[blue, thick] (A)--(O);
\draw[blue, thick] (O) --(B) node[above left, midway] { 3960 mi};

\draw[red, ultra thick] (A) arc(26:40:1.5) node[above right, midway, xshift=-2, yshift=-4, text=blue] {500 mi};

\node[text=red,yshift=1] at (32:1) {\small$\theta$};
    \end{tikzpicture}
}%
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
\par
To convert the angle measure to degrees, we multiply by \(\dfrac{180\degree}{\pi}\) to get%
\begin{equation*}
0.1263\left(\dfrac{180\degree}{\pi}\right) = 7.23\degree
\end{equation*}
Your latitude has changed by about \(7.23\degree\).%
\end{example}
\begin{inlineexercise}{Checkpoint}{}{exercise-Arclength-and-Radians-h-j}%
The distance around the face of a large clock from 2 to 3 is five feet. What is the radius of the clock?%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{\blocktitlefont Answer}.\hypertarget{answer-Arclength-and-Radians-h-j-b}{}\quad{}\(9.55\) ft%
\end{inlineexercise}%
\end{subsectionptx}

%
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection  Unit Circle}
\typeout{************************************************}
%
\begin{subsectionptx}{Subsection}{Unit Circle}{}{Unit Circle}{}{}{subsection-Arclength-and-Radians-i}
\index{unit circle!arclength and radians}%
In the rest of this chapter we will see how to use the trigonometric functions sine, cosine, and tangent when the input variable is measured in radians instead of degrees, and why making that change greatly increases the utility of those functions. In Section 4.1 we connected the sine and cosine to the coordinates of points on a \terminology{unit circle}, a circle of radius 1. Here is an important observation that will inform our study:%
\par
On a unit circle, \(r = 1\), so the arclength formula becomes \(s = \theta\). Thus, on a unit circle, an arc of length 1 determines a central angle of 1 radian, or about \(57.3 \degree\). And the measure of a (positive) angle in radians is equal to the length of the arc it spans. In other words, if we walk around the circle, each time we travel over an arclength of one radius, we turn through an angle of one radian.%
\begin{example}{Example}{}{example-Arclength-and-Radians-i-e}%
You are walking on a trail around a circular pond of radius one mile. You have have walked 4 miles from the trailhead. Sketch your location now.%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{\blocktitlefont Solution}.\hypertarget{solution-Arclength-and-Radians-i-e-b}{}\quad{}\begin{sidebyside}{2}{0}{0.05}{0.1}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.6}[center]%
The pond is a unit circle, so you have traversed an angle in radians equal to the arc length traveled, 4 miles. An angle of 4 radians is in the middle of the third quadrant relative to your starting point, more than halfway but less than three-quarters around the pond.%
\end{sbspanel}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.25}[center]%
\resizebox{\linewidth}{!}{%
\begin{tikzpicture}
\coordinate (O) at (0,0);
\draw[black, thick] (O) circle (1.5cm);
\coordinate (B) at ({deg(4)}:1.5);
\draw[gray, thick] (O)--++(1.5,0) node[below, midway, xshift=0, yshift=0] {\color{blue}$r=1$ mi};
\draw[blue, ultra thick, ->,>=stealth'] (1.5,0) arc (0:{deg(4)}:1.5) node[midway, xshift=-6, yshift=7]{4 mi};
\end{tikzpicture}
}%
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
\end{example}
\begin{inlineexercise}{Checkpoint}{}{exercise-Arclength-and-Radians-i-f}%
\begin{sidebyside}{2}{0}{0.1}{0.1}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.6}[center]%
An ant walks around the rim of a circular birdbath of diameter 2 feet. How far has the ant walked when it has turned through an angle of \(210\degree\)?%
\end{sbspanel}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.2}[center]%

\draw[black, dashed] (O) -- (B);
\draw[red, ->, >=stealth'] (.4,0) arc (0:210:.4) node[midway, xshift=0, yshift=6] {$210^\circ$};
\end{tikzpicture}
}%
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{\blocktitlefont Answer}.\hypertarget{answer-Arclength-and-Radians-i-f-b}{}\quad{}\(3.67\) ft%
\end{inlineexercise}%

\begin{subsubsectionptx}{Subsubsection}{Concepts}{}{Concepts}{}{}{subsubsection-Arclength-and-Radians-j-c}
%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*]
\item{}The distance we travel around a circle of radius  is proportional to the angle of displacement.%
\begin{equation*}
\textbf{Arclength}~ = ~ (\textbf{fraction of one revolution}) \cdot (2\pi r)
\end{equation*}
%
\item{}We measure angles in radians when we work with arclength.%
\begin{assemblage}{Assemblage}{Radians.}{assemblage-Arclength-and-Radians-j-c-b-a-b-b}%
The \terminology{radian measure} of an angle is given by%
\begin{equation*}
(\textbf{fraction of one revolution}\times 2\pi)
\end{equation*}
%
\end{assemblage}
\item{}An arclength equal to one radius determines a central angle of one radian.%
\item{}Radian measure can be expressed as multiples of \(\pi\) or as decimals.%
\begin{sidebyside}{2}{0.0125}{0.0125}{0.025}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.55}[center]%
\resizebox{\ifdim\width > \linewidth\linewidth\else\width\fi}{!}{%
{\centering%
{\tabularfont%
\begin{tabular}{AcAcAcA}\hrulethick
Degrees&\(\dfrac{\text{Radians:}}{\text{Exact Values}}\)&\(\dfrac{\text{Radians: Decimal}}{\text{Approximations}}\)\tabularnewline\hrulethin
\(0\degree\)&\(0\)&\(0\)\tabularnewline\hrulethin
\(90\degree\)&\(\dfrac{\pi}{2}\)&\(1.57\)\tabularnewline\hrulethin
\(180\degree\)&\(\pi\)&\(3.14\)\tabularnewline\hrulethin
\(270\degree\)&\(\dfrac{3\pi}{2}\)&\(4.71\)\tabularnewline\hrulethin
\(360\degree\)&\(2\pi\)&\(6.28\)\tabularnewline\hrulethin
\end{tabular}
}%
\par}
}%
\end{sbspanel}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.4}[center]%
\resizebox{\linewidth}{!}{%
\begin{tikzpicture}[scale=.8]
\coordinate (O) at (0,0);
\draw[gray!90!white,thick] (O) circle (1.5cm);
\coordinate (A) at (0:1.5);
\coordinate (B) at (90:1.5);
\coordinate (C) at (180:1.5);
\coordinate (D) at (270:1.5);

\draw[black,thick] (-1.7,0)--(1.7,0);
\draw[black,thick] (0,-1.7)--(0,1.7);
\draw[red, fill=red] (A) circle (1.5pt) node[anchor=south west, text=blue] {0};
\draw[red, fill=red] (A) circle (1.5pt) node[anchor=north west, text=blue] {$2\pi \approx 6.28$};
\draw[red, fill=red] (B) circle (1.5pt) node[anchor=south west, text=blue] {$\dfrac{\pi}{2}\approx 1.57$};
\draw[red, fill=red] (C) circle (1.5pt) node[anchor=south east, text=blue] {$\pi\approx 3.14$};
\draw[red, fill=red] (D) circle (1.5pt) node[anchor=north, yshift=-3, text=blue] {$\dfrac{3\pi}{2}\approx 4.71$};
\end{tikzpicture}
}%
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
\item{}We multiply by the appropriate conversion factor to convert between degrees and radians.%
\begin{assemblage}{Assemblage}{Unit Conversion for Angles.}{assemblage-Arclength-and-Radians-j-c-b-a-e-b}%
%
\begin{equation*}
\dfrac{180\degree}{\pi~\text{radians}} = 1
\end{equation*}
%
\end{assemblage}
To convert from radians to degrees we multiply the radian measure by \(\dfrac{180\degree}{\pi}\).%
\par
To convert from degrees to radians we multiply the degree measure by \(\dfrac{\pi}{180}\).%
\item{}\begin{assemblage}{Assemblage}{Arclength Formula.}{assemblage-Arclength-and-Radians-j-c-b-a-f-a}%
On a circle of radius \(r\), the \terminology{length \(s\) of an arc} spanned by an angle \(\theta\) in radians is%
\begin{equation*}
s = r\theta
\end{equation*}
%
\end{assemblage}
%
\item{}On a \terminology{unit circle}, the measure of a (positive) angle in radians is equal to the length of the arc it spans.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{subsubsectionptx}

\begin{exercisegroup}
\begin{divisionexerciseeg}{33}{}{}{exercise-hmwk-6-1-exercises-n-b}%

\textbf{Exercise Group.}\space\space%

\begin{exercisegroup}
\begin{divisionexerciseeg}{39}{}{}{exercise-hmwk-6-1-exercises-o-b}%
%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*]
\item{}Through how many radians does the minute hand of a clock sweep between 9:05 pm and 9:30 pm?%
\item{}The dial of Big Ben's clock in London is 23 feet in diameter. How long is the arc traced by the minute hand between 9:05 pm and 9:30 pm?%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{divisionexerciseeg}%
\begin{divisionexerciseeg}{40}{}{}{exercise-hmwk-6-1-exercises-o-c}%
The largest clock ever constructed was the Floral Clock in the garden of the 1904 World's Fair in St. Louis. The hour hand was 50 feet long, the minute hand was 75 feet long, and the radius of the clockface was 112 feet.%
\par
%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*]
\item{}If you started at the 12 and walked 500 feet clockwise around the clockface, through how many radians would you walk?%
\item{}If you started your walk at noon, how long would it take the minute hand to reach your position?  How far did the tip of the minute hand move in its arc?%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{divisionexerciseeg}%
\begin{divisionexerciseeg}{41}{}{}{exercise-hmwk-6-1-exercises-o-d}%
In 1851 Jean-Bernard Foucault demonstrated the rotation of the earth with a pendulum installed in the Pantheon in Paris.  Foucault's pendulum consisted of a cannonball suspended on a 67 meter wire, and it swept out an arc of 8 meters on each swing. Through what angle did the pendulum swing? Give your answer in radians and then in degrees, rounded to the nearest hundredth.%
\end{divisionexerciseeg}%
\begin{divisionexerciseeg}{42}{}{}{exercise-hmwk-6-1-exercises-o-e}%
A wheel with radius 40 centimeters is rolled a distance of 1000 centimeters on a flat surface.  Through what angle has the wheel rotated? Give your answer in radians and then in degrees, rounded to one decimal place.%
\end{divisionexerciseeg}%
\begin{divisionexerciseeg}{43}{}{}{exercise-hmwk-6-1-exercises-o-f}%
Clothes dryers draw 3.5 times as much power as washing machines, so newer machines have been engineered for greater efficiency. A vigorous spin cycle reduces the time needed for drying, and some front-loading models spin at a rate of 1500 rotations per minute.%
\par
%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*]
\item{}If the radius of the drum is 11 inches, how far do your socks travel in one minute?%
\item{}How fast are your socks traveling during the spin cycle?%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{divisionexerciseeg}%
\begin{divisionexerciseeg}{44}{}{}{exercise-hmwk-6-1-exercises-o-g}%
The Hubble telescope is in orbit around the earth at an altitude of 600 kilometers, and completes one orbit in 97 minutes.%
\par
%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*]
\item{}How far does the telescope travel in one hour? (The radius of the earth is 6400 kilometers.)%
\item{}What is the speed of the Hubble telescope?%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{divisionexerciseeg}%
\begin{divisionexerciseeg}{45}{}{}{exercise-hmwk-6-1-exercises-o-h}%
The first large windmill used to generate electricity was built in Cleveland, Ohio in 1888. Its sails were 17 meters in diameter, and moved at 10 rotations per minute. How fast did the ends of the sails travel?%
\end{divisionexerciseeg}%
\begin{divisionexerciseeg}{46}{}{}{exercise-hmwk-6-1-exercises-o-i}%
The largest windmill operating today has wings 54 meters in length. To be most efficient, the tips of the wings must travel at 50 meters per second. How fast must the wings rotate?%
\end{divisionexerciseeg}%
\end{exercisegroup}

\begin{divisionexercise}{55}{}{}{exercise-hmwk-6-1-exercises-s}%
The angular velocity, \(\omega\), of a rotating object is given in radians per unit time.  Thus, an object that rotates through \(\theta\) radians in time \(t\) has angular velocity given by \(\omega = \dfrac{\theta}{t}\). Find the angular velocity of the following objects.%
\par
%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*]
\item{}The London Eye ferris wheel, which makes one revolution every 20 minutes.%
\item{}An old-fashioned long-playing record, which revolved \(33\frac{1}{3}\) times in 60 seconds.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{divisionexercise}%
\begin{divisionexercise}{56}{}{}{exercise-hmwk-6-1-exercises-t}%
Use the arclength formula to derive a formula relating linear velocity, \(v\), and angular velocity, \(\omega\). (See Problem 55 for the definition of angular velocity.) Start with the formula for linear velocity:%
\begin{equation*}
\text{velocity} = \dfrac{\text{distance}}{\text{time}},~~~ \text{or} ~~~ v = \dfrac{s}{t}
\end{equation*}
and substitute the arclength formula for \(s\).%
\end{divisionexercise}%
\begin{divisionexercise}{57}{}{}{exercise-hmwk-6-1-exercises-u}%
Recall that to calculate a fraction of a revolution in degrees we divide the angle by \(360\degree\).  For example, \(90\degree\) is \(\dfrac{1}{4}\) of a revolution because \(\dfrac{90\degree}{360\degree} = \dfrac{1}{4}\).%
\par
%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*]
\item{}Write an expression that gives the fraction of a revolution for an angle \(\theta\) in radians.%
\item{}Use your expression to calculate what fraction of a revolution is represented by each of the following angles: \(~\theta = \dfrac{3\pi}{4}, ~~ \theta = \dfrac{5\pi}{3}, ~~ \theta = \dfrac{7\pi}{6}\).%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{divisionexercise}%
\begin{divisionexercise}{58}{}{}{exercise-hmwk-6-1-exercises-v}%

\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection  Trigonometric Functions of Angles in Radians}
\typeout{************************************************}
%
\begin{subsectionptx}{Subsection}{Trigonometric Functions of Angles in Radians}{}{Trigonometric Functions of Angles in Radians}{}{}{subsection-The-Circular-Functions-b}
Measuring angles in radians has other applications besides calculating arclength, and we will need to evaluate trigonometric functions of angles in radians. The sine, cosine, or tangent of a particular angle is the same whether the angle is measured in radians or in degrees.%
\par
In Section 4.1 we saw that the sine and cosine are related to points on a unit circle.%
\begin{assemblage}{Assemblage}{Angles in a Unit Circle.}{assemblage-The-Circular-Functions-b-d}%
Let \(P\) be a point on a unit circle determined by the terminal side of an angle \(\theta\) in standard position. Then the coordinates \((x,y)\)  of \(P\) are given by%
\begin{equation*}
\blert{x = \cos (\theta),~~~~~~y = \sin (\theta)}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{assemblage}
This fact follows easily from the definitions of sine and cosine, because on a unit circle \(r=1\). In the next Activity we'll use this relationship to get a feel for the trig values of angles in radians.%
\begin{activity}{Activity}{Trigonometry in Radians.}{activity-The-Circular-Functions-b-f}%
\index{radian}%
\index{radian}%
Here is a unit circle with arclengths labeled, measured counterclockwise from \((1,0)\). (Note that the distance around the whole circle is 6.28 units!) In Section 6.1 we learned that on a unit circle, the measure of a positive angle in radians is equal to the length of the arc that it spans.%
\begin{sidebyside}{1}{0.15}{0.15}{0}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.7}%
\resizebox{\linewidth}{!}{%
\begin{tikzpicture} [scale=3.6]

\draw[cyan] (-1.0001,-1.0001) grid[step = 0.1] (1,1);
\draw[black, thick] (-1,0)--(1,0);
\draw[black, thick] (0,-1)--(0,1);

\draw[red,thick] (0,0) circle (1cm);

\foreach \i in {0.1, 0.2, ..., 6.2} {
 \draw[black, thick] ({deg(\i)}:1) -- ({deg(\i)}:1.03);
};
\foreach \i in {0.5, 1.5, ..., 5.5} {
 \draw[black, thick] ({deg(\i)}:1) -- ({deg(\i)}:1.06);
 \node[text width=.4cm, fill=white, inner sep=1] at ({deg(\i)}:1.15) { \i};
};
\foreach \i in {1,2, ..., 6} {
 \draw[black, thick] ({deg(\i)}:1) -- ({deg(\i)}:1.1);
 \node[text width=.2cm, fill=white, inner sep=1] at ({deg(\i)}:1.15) { \i};
};
\foreach \i in {-0.5, 0.5} {
 \draw[black, thick] (0.03,\i) -- (-0.03,\i) node[left, fill=white, inner sep=1]{ \i};
 \draw[black, thick] (\i,0.03) -- (\i,-0.03) node[below, fill=white, inner sep=1]{\i};
};
\end{tikzpicture}
}%
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
\par
%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*]
\item{}Use the unit circle to estimate the sine, cosine, and tangent of each angle in radians.%
\begin{multicols}{4}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*]
\item{}\(\displaystyle 0.6\)%
\item{}\(\displaystyle 2.3\)%
\item{}\(\displaystyle 3.5\)%
\item{}\(\displaystyle 5.3\)%
\end{enumerate}
\end{multicols}
%
\item{}Use the unit circle to estimate two solutions to each equation.%
\begin{multicols}{2}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*]
\item{}\(\displaystyle \cos (\theta) = 0.3\)%
\item{}\(\displaystyle \sin (\theta) = 0.7\)%
\end{enumerate}
\end{multicols}
%
\item{}Sketch the angle on the unit circle. Use symmetry to find three more angles with the same sine and cosine, up to sign.%
\begin{multicols}{4}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*]
\item{}\(\displaystyle 1.8\)%
\item{}\(\displaystyle 5.2\)%
\item{}\(\displaystyle 3.7\)%
\item{}\(\displaystyle 0.3\)%
\end{enumerate}
\end{multicols}
%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{activity}%
\end{subsectionptx}

%
\begin{subsectionptx}{Subsection}{Using a Calculator}{}{Using a Calculator}{}{}{subsection-The-Circular-Functions-c}
Your calculator can give you the trigonometric function values for angles expressed in radians. For example, \(\dfrac{\pi}{3}\) radians is the same as \(60\degree\), because \(\dfrac{\pi}{3} \cdot \dfrac{180\degree}{\pi} = 60\degree\), so%
\begin{equation*}
\sin \left(\dfrac{\pi}{3}\right) = \sin (60\degree) = \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}
\end{equation*}
However, we don't have to convert radians to degrees in order to evaluate trig ratios. First, change the calculator setting from Degree mode to Radian mode. Then enter%
\begin{equation*}
\sin ~(\pi \div  3)
\end{equation*}
and the calculator will return \(0.8660254038\). You can check that this number is a decimal approximation for \(\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\).%
\begin{example}{Example}{}{example-The-Circular-Functions-c-c}%
Use your calculator to find the sine and cosine of the following angles in radians. Round your answers to four decimal places.%
\par
%
\begin{multicols}{2}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*]
\item{}\(\displaystyle \theta = \dfrac{7\pi}{4}\)%
\item{}\(\displaystyle \theta = 3.5\)%
\end{enumerate}
\end{multicols}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{\blocktitlefont Solution}.\hypertarget{solution-The-Circular-Functions-c-c-b}{}\quad{}%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*]
\item{}With the calculator in radian mode, and rounding to four decimal places we find%
\begin{align*}
\cos (7\pi/4) \amp = 0.7071\\
\sin (7\pi/4) \amp = -0.7071
\end{align*}
%
\item{}Your calculator will also give you the values%
\begin{align*}
\cos (3.5) \amp = -0.9365\\
\sin (3.5) \amp = -0.3508
\end{align*}
rounded to four places. Note that 3.5 radians is a third-quadrant angle, so the signs of the trig values make sense.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\begin{inlineexercise}{Checkpoint}{}{exercise-The-Circular-Functions-c-d}%
Use your calculator to find the tangents of the following angles in radians. Round your answers to four decimal places.%
\par
%
\begin{multicols}{2}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*]
\item{}\(\displaystyle \theta = \dfrac{5\pi}{12}\)%
\item{}\(\displaystyle \theta = 5.2\)%
\end{enumerate}
\end{multicols}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{\blocktitlefont Answer}.\hypertarget{answer-The-Circular-Functions-c-d-b}{}\quad{}%
\begin{multicols}{2}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*]
\item{}\(\displaystyle 3.7321\)%
\item{}\(\displaystyle -1.8856\)%
\end{enumerate}
\end{multicols}
%
\end{inlineexercise}%
If two angles are coterminal they have the same trig values, just as they do when measured in degrees. So adding or subtracting a multiple of \(2 \pi\) to any angle results in a new angle in the same standard position and with the same trig values.%
\begin{example}{Example}{}{example-The-Circular-Functions-c-f}%
Find the sine and cosine of the following angles in radians. Round your answers to four decimal places.%
\par
%
\begin{multicols}{2}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*]
\item{}\(\displaystyle \theta = \dfrac{5\pi}{2}\)%
\item{}\(\displaystyle \theta = - 4\)%
\end{enumerate}
\end{multicols}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{\blocktitlefont Solution}.\hypertarget{solution-The-Circular-Functions-c-f-b}{}\quad{}%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*]
\item{}Because \(\dfrac{5\pi}{2} = 2\pi + \dfrac{\pi}{2},~\) \(\theta\) is coterminal with \(\dfrac{\pi}{2},~\) and it has the same sine and cosine as \(\dfrac{\pi}{2}\).  And \(\dfrac{\pi}{2}\) radians is equal to \(90\degree\), so%
\begin{gather*}
\sin (\theta) = \sin \left(\dfrac{\pi}{2}\right) = 1\\
\cos (\theta) = \cos \left(\dfrac{\pi}{2}\right) = 0
\end{gather*}
%
\item{}Rounded to four places, your calculator will give you the values%
\begin{align*}
\cos (-4) \amp = -0.6536\\
\sin (-4) \amp = 0.7568
\end{align*}
By adding 6.2832 (that's approximately \(2\pi\)) to \(-4\) we see that \(-4\) radians is coterminal with \(2.2832\) radians, a second-quadrant angle. You can check that \(2.2832\) radians has (approximately) the same trig values as \(-4\) radians.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\begin{inlineexercise}{Checkpoint}{}{exercise-The-Circular-Functions-c-g}%
Use your calculator to find the tangent of the following angles in radians. Round your answers to four decimal places.%
\par
%
\begin{multicols}{2}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*]
\item{}\(\displaystyle \theta = -\dfrac{3\pi}{4}\)%
\item{}\(\displaystyle \theta = 15\)%
\end{enumerate}
\end{multicols}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{\blocktitlefont Answer}.\hypertarget{answer-The-Circular-Functions-c-g-b}{}\quad{}%
\begin{multicols}{2}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*]
\item{}\(\displaystyle 1\)%
\item{}\(\displaystyle -0.8560\)%
\end{enumerate}
\end{multicols}
%
\end{inlineexercise}%
Recall the formula for arclength when the angle is measured in radians:  \(s = r \theta\). If we solve for \(\theta\), we see that \(\theta = \dfrac{s}{r}\), a ratio of two lengths. The units of length cancel out, so that radian measure has no units; it is a "dimensionless" quantity. In other words, a radian measure is just a real number.%
\par
We shall see that this property makes radians especially useful in applications. From now on we shall omit the tag "radians," and you may assume that any angle given without units is in radians.%
\end{subsectionptx}
%
%
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection  Sine and Cosine of Real Numbers}
\typeout{************************************************}
%
\begin{subsectionptx}{Subsection}{Sine and Cosine of Real Numbers}{}{Sine and Cosine of Real Numbers}{}{}{subsection-The-Circular-Functions-d}
\index{sine!of a real number}%
\index{cosine!of a real number}%
We have observed that the measure of an angle in radians is just a real number. This is an important observation, because it allows us to define the sine and cosine as functions of real numbers, instead of as functions of angles.%
\begin{assemblage}{Assemblage}{Sine and Cosine of Real Numbers.}{assemblage-The-Circular-Functions-d-e}%
We define the trigonometric functions of the real number \(t\) by%
\begin{equation*}
\blert{\cos (t) = \cos (\theta)} ~~~~\text{and} ~~~~ \blert{\sin (t) = \sin (\theta)}
\end{equation*}
where \(\theta = t~\) is an angle measured in radians.%
\end{assemblage}
We can think of the definition this way: to find the sine or cosine of a real number \(t\), we find the sine or cosine of the angle \(\theta = t\) in radians.%
\begin{note}{Note}{}{note-The-Circular-Functions-d-g}%
To understand the connection between real numbers and radians, you may find it helpful to remember that the measure of a positive angle in radians is equal to the length of the arc it spans on a unit circle.%
\begin{sidebyside}{2}{0}{0.05}{0.02}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.65}[center]%
Consider the unit circle shown at right, and the angle \(\theta\) determined by the arc of length \(t\). The radian measure of \(\theta\) is the same as the length \(t\) of the arc. (For example, in this figure \(\theta = t = 2\).)%
\end{sbspanel}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.28}[center]%
\resizebox{\linewidth}{!}{%
\begin{tikzpicture} [scale=.9]
\coordinate (O) at (0,0);
\coordinate (A) at (0:1.5);
\coordinate (B) at ($({deg(2)}:1.5)$);
\coordinate (C) at ($ 1.5*cos(deg(2))*(1,0) $);
\coordinate (D) at ($ 1.5*sin(deg(2))*(0,1) $);

\draw[black, thick, ->,>=stealth'] (-1.7,0)--(1.8,0);
\draw[black, thick, ->,>=stealth'] (0,-1.7)--(0,1.8);
\draw[gray, thick] (O) circle (1.5);

\draw[black, thick] (O)--(B) ;
\draw[red, thick, ->,>=stealth'] (0.3,0) arc(0:{deg(2)}:0.3)  node[above right, midway, xshift=-2] {$\theta=2$};
\draw[blue, ultra thick] (1.5,0) arc(0:{deg(2)}:1.5)  node[above right, midway, xshift=-2] {$t=2$};
\filldraw[black] (B) circle (.06cm);
\end{tikzpicture}
}%
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
\par
In practice, there is no difference between finding the sine or cosine of the number 2 and the sine or cosine of an angle of 2 radians: in each case we set the calculator in Radian mode and evaluate%
%
\begin{equation*}
\cos~(2) = -0.4161 ~~~~~~ \text{and} ~~~~~ \sin ~(2) = 0.9093
\end{equation*}
\end{note}
So, in some sense then, a trig function of a radian is the same as a trig function of a real number. This result is so important that it bears repeating: to find the sine or cosine of a real number \(t\), we find the sine or cosine of the angle \(t\) radians. We can now use the trigonometric functions to model periodic behavior as functions of time, or indeed, of any variable.%
\begin{example}{Example}{}{example-The-Circular-Functions-d-i}%
The sunset time in Stockholm, Sweden, on the \(n\)th day of the year can be modeled by%
\begin{equation*}
T = 3.11 ~\sin ~(0.017n - 1.38) + 6.03
\end{equation*}
where \(T\) is given in hours after noon. Find the sunset time on January 1 (day \(n = 1\)) and on July 1 (day \(n = 182\)).%
\begin{sidebyside}{1}{0.025}{0.025}{0}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.95}%
\resizebox{\linewidth}{!}{%
\begin{tikzpicture} [xscale=.3, yscale=.3]
\draw[cyan] (0,0) grid (37,10);
\draw[->,>=stealth'] (0,0) -- (38,0) node[right] {$n$};
\draw[->,>=stealth'] (0,0) -- (0,10.7) node[above] {$T$};
\foreach \x [evaluate =\x as \xi using int(10*\x] in {5,10,...,35}
  \draw[black] (\x, .15) --++(0,-.3) node[below]{$\xi$};
\foreach \y in {5,10}
  \draw[black, thick] (.2,\y ) --++(-.4,0) node[anchor=east, xshift=-3] {$\y$};
\draw[samples=65,domain=0:36.5,smooth,variable=\x,red,very thick] plot ({\x},{6.03+3.11*sin(deg(.17*\x-1.38))});
\node[text width=5cm] at (18.5,10.7)    {Sunset Time in Stockholm};
\filldraw[red] (0.1,{6.03+3.11*sin(deg(.017-1.38))}) ellipse (.2cm and .2cm);
\filldraw[red] (18.2,{6.03+3.11*sin(deg(.017*182-1.38))}) ellipse (.2cm and .2cm);
\end{tikzpicture}
}%
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{\blocktitlefont Solution}.\hypertarget{solution-The-Circular-Functions-d-i-b}{}\quad{}Evaluate the function for \(n = \alert{1}\) to find%
\begin{equation*}
T = 3.11 ~\sin ~(0.017(\alert{1}) - 1.38) + 6.03 = 2.99
\end{equation*}
On January 1, sunset in Stockholm occurs about 2.99 hours after noon, or at 2:59 pm.%
\par
Evaluate the function at \(n = \alert{182}\) to find%
\begin{equation*}
T = 3.11 ~\sin ~(0.017(\alert{182}) - 1.38) + 6.03 = 9.11
\end{equation*}
On July 1, sunset occurs about 9.11 hours after noon, or at 9:07 pm. (Actually, 10:07 pm, because of daylight savings time.)%
\end{example}
\begin{inlineexercise}{Checkpoint}{}{exercise-The-Circular-Functions-d-j}%

The star T Herculis reached its minimum magnitude on December 27, 2004, and \(t\) days later its magnitude is approximately%
\begin{equation*}
M = 10.2 - 2.2 ~\cos~(0.038t)
\end{equation*}
%
\begin{sidebyside}{1}{0.025}{0.025}{0}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.95}%
\resizebox{\linewidth}{!}{%
\begin{tikzpicture} [xscale=.3, yscale=.3]

\draw[->,>=stealth'] (0,0) -- (38,0) node[right] {$t$};
\draw[->,>=stealth'] (0,0) -- (0,15.8) node[above] {$M$};    
\foreach \x [evaluate =\x as \xi using int(20*\x] in {5,10,...,35}
  \draw[black] (\x, .15) --++(0,-.3) node[below]{$\xi$};
\foreach \y in {5,10,15}
  \draw[black, thick] (.2,\y ) --++(-.4,0) node[anchor=east, xshift=-3] {$\y$};    
\draw[samples=65,domain=0:37,smooth,variable=\x,red,very thick] plot ({\x},{10.2-2.2*cos(deg(0.038*\x*20))});
\node[text width=5cm] at (18.5,15.8)    {Magnitude of T Herculis};
\filldraw[red] (0,{10.2-2.2*cos(deg(0.038*0))}) ellipse (.2cm and .2cm);

\par
%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*]
\item{}What was the magnitude of T Herculis on December 27, 2004?%
\item{}What was the magnitude of T Herculis be on December 27, 2006 (730 days later)?%
\end{enumerate}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{\blocktitlefont Answer}.\hypertarget{answer-The-Circular-Functions-d-j-b}{}\quad{}%
\begin{multicols}{2}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*]
\item{}\(\displaystyle 8\)%
\item{}\(\displaystyle 12.09\)%
\end{enumerate}
\end{multicols}
%
\end{inlineexercise}%
\end{subsectionptx}

\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection  The Tangent Function}
\typeout{************************************************}
%
\begin{subsectionptx}{Subsection}{The Tangent Function}{}{The Tangent Function}{}{}{subsection-The-Circular-Functions-e}
\index{tangent function}%
We can also define the tangent function for real numbers. Let \(P(x,y)\) be the terminal point of an arc of length \(t\) in standard position on a unit circle. Then%
\begin{equation*}
\blert{\tan (t) = \dfrac{y}{x}}
\end{equation*}
Of course, this definition agrees with our earlier definition of the tangent function for angles, because the point \(P\) lies on the terminal side of the angle \(\theta = t\) radians.%
\begin{sidebyside}{2}{0}{0}{0.05}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.65}[center]%
For example, we saw earlier that, rounded to four decimal places,%
\begin{equation*}
\cos (2) = -0.4161~~~~\text{and} ~~~~ \sin (2) = 0.9093
\end{equation*}
so the coordinates of point \(P\) on the unit circle in the figure at right are \((-0.4161, 0.9093)\). Therefore,%
\begin{equation*}
\tan (2) = \dfrac{0.9093}{-0.4161} = -2.1853
\end{equation*}
%
\end{sbspanel}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.3}[center]%
\resizebox{\linewidth}{!}{%
\begin{tikzpicture}

\coordinate (O) at (0,0);
\coordinate (A) at (0:1.5);
\coordinate (B) at ($ ({deg(2)}:1.5) $);
\coordinate (C) at ($ 1.5*cos(deg(2))*(1,0) $);
\coordinate (D) at ($ 1.5*sin(deg(2))*(0,0) $);

\draw[black, thick, ->,>=stealth'] (-1.7,0)--(1.8,0);
\draw[black, thick, ->,>=stealth'] (0,-1.7)--(0,1.8);
\draw[gray, thick, dashed] (C)--(B)--(D);
\draw[black, thick] (O)--(B);
\draw[gray, thick] (O) circle (1.5);

\draw[red, thick, ->,>=stealth'] (0.3,0) arc(0:{deg(2)}:0.3)  node[above right, midway] {$\theta=2$};
\draw[blue, ultra thick] (1.5,0) arc(0:{deg(2)}:1.5)  node[above right, midway, xshift=6] {$t=2$};
\filldraw[black] (B) circle (.06cm) node[above left]{$P(x,y)$};
\end{tikzpicture}
}%
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
\par
You can set your calculator in radian mode to verify that, to three decimal places,%
\begin{equation*}
\tan (2) = -2.185
\end{equation*}
%
\par
Because the trig values can be found as coordinates on a unit circle, our three trig functions are often called the \terminology{circular functions}. We now have the following definitions for the circular functions of real numbers.%
\begin{assemblage}{Assemblage}{The Circular Functions.}{assemblage-The-Circular-Functions-e-g}%
Let \(P\) be the terminal point of an arc of length \(t\) in standard position on a unit circle. The \terminology{circular functions} of \(t\) are defined by%
\begin{sidebyside}{2}{0.1}{0.1}{0.05}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.4}[center]%
%
\begin{align*}
\blert{\cos (t)~} \amp \blert{= x}\\
\blert{\sin (t)~} \amp \blert{= y}\\
\blert{\tan (t)~} \amp \blert{= \dfrac{y}{x},~~~~x \not= 0}
\end{align*}
%
\end{sbspanel}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.35}[center]%
\resizebox{\linewidth}{!}{%
\begin{tikzpicture}[scale=.8]
    \coordinate (O) at (0,0);
    \coordinate (A) at (0:1.5);
    \coordinate (B) at (140:1.5);

    \draw[black, thick, ->,>=stealth'] (-1.7,0)--(2,0);
    \draw[black, thick, ->,>=stealth'] (0,-1.7)--(0,1.9);
    \draw[gray, thick] (O) circle (1.5);

    \draw[blue, ultra thick] (1.5,0) arc(0:140:1.5)  node[above right, midway, xshift=3, yshift=-2] {$t$};
    \filldraw[black] (A) circle (.1cm) node[anchor=north west, yshift=-5] { $(1,0)$};
    \filldraw[black] (B) circle (.1cm) node[anchor=south east, yshift=-1] { $(x,y)$};
\end{tikzpicture}
}%
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
\end{assemblage}
\begin{example}{Example}{}{example-The-Circular-Functions-e-h}%
Use the graph of the unit circle shown below to estimate \(\cos (2.5),~\sin (2.5)\), and \(\tan (2.5)\).%
\begin{sidebyside}{1}{0.2}{0.2}{0}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.6}%
\resizebox{\linewidth}{!}{%
\begin{tikzpicture} [scale=3.6]

\draw[cyan] (-1.0001,-1.0001) grid[step = 0.1] (1,1);
\draw[black, thick] (-1,0)--(1,0);
\draw[black, thick] (0,-1)--(0,1);

\draw[red,thick] (0,0) circle (1cm);

\foreach \i in {0.1, 0.2, ..., 6.2} {
    \draw[black, thick] ({deg(\i)}:1) -- ({deg(\i)}:1.03);
};
\foreach \i in {0.5, 1.5, ..., 5.5} {
    \draw[black, thick] ({deg(\i)}:1) -- ({deg(\i)}:1.06);
    \node[text width=.4cm, fill=white, inner sep=1] at ({deg(\i)}:1.15) { \i};
};
\foreach \i in {1,2, ..., 6} {
    \draw[black, thick] ({deg(\i)}:1) -- ({deg(\i)}:1.1);
    \node[text width=.2cm, fill=white, inner sep=1] at ({deg(\i)}:1.15) { \i};
};
\foreach \i in {-0.5, 0.5} {
    \draw[black, thick] (0.03,\i) -- (-0.03,\i) node[left, fill=white, inner sep=1]{ \i};
    \draw[black, thick] (\i,0.03) -- (\i,-0.03) node[below, fill=white, inner sep=1]{\i};
};
\end{tikzpicture}
}%
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{\blocktitlefont Solution}.\hypertarget{solution-The-Circular-Functions-e-h-b}{}\quad{}The circle is scaled in units of 0.1 radians, and an arc of 2.5 radians in standard position has its terminal point, \(P\), in the second quadrant. The coordinates of \(P\) are approximately \((-0.8,0.6)\), so we have%
\begin{equation*}
\cos (2.5) = -0.8~~~~\text{and}~~~~\sin (2.5) = 0.6
\end{equation*}
To find \(\tan (2.5)\),  we calculate \(\dfrac{y}{x}\).%
\begin{equation*}
\tan (2.5) = \dfrac{y}{x} = \dfrac{0.6}{-0.8} = -0.75
\end{equation*}
%
\end{example}

\end{subsectionptx}

\begin{subsectionptx}{Subsection}{The Special Values}{}{The Special Values}{}{}{subsection-The-Circular-Functions-f}
\index{special angles!radians}%
In Chapter 2 you learned the exact trig values for the "special angles" \(30 \degree,~ 45 \degree\) and \(60 \degree\). Recall that the trig values for these angles can be used as benchmarks for estimating and mental calculation.  Now we review those values when the angles are measured in radians.%

\begin{example}{Example}{}{example-The-Circular-Functions-f-j}%
Give exact values for the following.%
\par
%
\begin{multicols}{2}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*]
\item{}\(\displaystyle \tan \left(\dfrac{2\pi}{3}\right)\)%
\item{}\(\displaystyle \cos \left(\dfrac{5\pi}{4}\right)\)%
\end{enumerate}
\end{multicols}
%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{\blocktitlefont Solution}.\hypertarget{solution-The-Circular-Functions-f-j-b}{}\quad{}%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*]
\item{}\begin{sidebyside}{2}{0.0125}{0.0125}{0.025}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.6}[center]%
The reference angle for \(\dfrac{2\pi}{3}\) is \(\pi - \dfrac{2\pi}{3} = \dfrac{\pi}{3}\), and the tangent is negative in the second quadrant. (See the figure at right.)  Thus,%
\begin{equation*}
\tan \left(\dfrac{2\pi}{3}\right) = -\tan \left(\dfrac{\pi}{3}\right) = -\sqrt{3}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{sbspanel}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.35}[center]%
\resizebox{\linewidth}{!}{%
\begin{tikzpicture}     
\coordinate (O) at (0,0);
\coordinate (A) at (60:1.5);
\coordinate (B) at (120:1.5);
\coordinate (C) at (0.75,0);
\coordinate (D) at (-0.75,0);

\draw[blue,thick] (C) rectangle ++(-.2,.2);
\draw[blue,thick] (D) rectangle ++(.2,.2);

\draw[black, thick, ->,>=stealth'] (-1.7,0)--(1.8,0);
\draw[black, thick, ->,>=stealth'] (0,-1.7)--(0,1.8);
\draw[gray, thick] (O) circle (1.5);

\draw[gray!80, thick, dashed] (O)--(A)--(C);
\draw[blue, thick] (O)--(B) ;
\draw[gray!80, thick, dashed] (B)--(D) ;
\draw[red, thick, ->,>=stealth'] (0.4,0) arc(0:120:0.4);
\draw[red, thick, ->,>=stealth'] (-0.5,0) arc(180:120:0.5);
\filldraw[black] (A) circle (.06cm) node[anchor=south west, yshift=-0.1cm, text=red] {$s=\dfrac{\pi}{3}$};
\filldraw[black] (B) circle (.06cm) node[anchor=south east, yshift=-0.1cm, text=red] {$s=\dfrac{2\pi}{3}$};
\end{tikzpicture}
}%
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
%
\item{}\begin{sidebyside}{2}{0.0125}{0.0125}{0.025}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.6}[center]%
The reference angle for \(\dfrac{5\pi}{4}\) is \(\dfrac{5\pi}{4} - \pi = \dfrac{\pi}{4}\), and the cosine is negative in the third quadrant, so%
\begin{equation*}
\cos \left(\dfrac{5\pi}{4}\right) = - \cos \left(\dfrac{\pi}{4}\right) = \dfrac{-1}{\sqrt{2}}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{sbspanel}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.35}[center]%
\resizebox{\linewidth}{!}{%
\begin{tikzpicture} [scale=.9]  
\coordinate (O) at (0,0);
\coordinate (A) at (45:1.5);
\coordinate (B) at (225:1.5);
\coordinate (C) at ($ sqrt(2)*(.75,0) $);
\coordinate (D) at ($ -sqrt(2)*(.75,0) $);

\draw[blue,thick] (C) rectangle ++(-.2,.2);
\draw[blue,thick] (D) rectangle ++(.2,-.2);

\draw[black, thick, ->,>=stealth'] (-1.7,0)--(1.8,0);
\draw[black, thick, ->,>=stealth'] (0,-1.7)--(0,1.8);
\draw[gray, thick] (O) circle (1.5);

\draw[gray!80, thick, dashed] (O)--(A)--(C);
\draw[blue, thick] (O)--(B) ;
\draw[gray!80, thick, dashed] (B)--(D) ;
\draw[red, thick, ->,>=stealth'] (0.4,0) arc(0:225:0.4);
\draw[red, thick, ->,>=stealth'] (-0.6,0) arc(180:225:0.6);
\filldraw[black] (A) circle (.06cm) node[anchor=south west, yshift=-0.1cm, text=red] {$s=\dfrac{\pi}{4}$};
\filldraw[black] (B) circle (.06cm) node[anchor=north east, yshift=0.1cm, text=red] {$s=\dfrac{5\pi}{4}$};
\end{tikzpicture}
}%
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{example}
\begin{note}{Note}{}{note-The-Circular-Functions-f-k}%
At this point, you may feel that expressions such as \(~\cos \left(\dfrac{5\pi}{4}\right) = \dfrac{-1}{\sqrt{2}}~\) look like hieroglyphics.  Keep in mind that \(\dfrac{5\pi}{4}\) and \(\dfrac{-1}{\sqrt{2}}\) are just numbers, so the equation above says that "the cosine of an angle of 3.9 radians is about -0.7."%
\end{note}

\begin{example}{Example}{}{example-The-Circular-Functions-f-n}%
Find the coordinates of the terminal point, \(P\), of an arc of length \(t = \dfrac{5\pi}{6}\) starting at \((1,0)\) on a unit circle.%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{\blocktitlefont Solution}.\hypertarget{solution-The-Circular-Functions-f-n-b}{}\quad{}The coordinates of \(P\) are \(\left(\cos \dfrac{5\pi}{6}, \sin \dfrac{5\pi}{6}\right)\), so%
\begin{sidebyside}{2}{0}{0.05}{0.12}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.5}[center]%
%
\begin{align*}
x \amp= \cos \left(\dfrac{5\pi}{6}\right) = \dfrac{-\sqrt{3}}{2}~~~\\
y \amp= \sin \left(\dfrac{5\pi}{6}\right) = \dfrac{1}{2}
\end{align*}
%
\end{sbspanel}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.33}[center]%
\resizebox{\linewidth}{!}{%
\begin{tikzpicture}[scale=.9]
\coordinate (O) at (0,0);
\coordinate (A) at (0:1.5);
\coordinate (B) at (150:1.5);

\draw[black, thick, ->,>=stealth'] (-1.7,0)--(1.8,0);
\draw[black, thick, ->,>=stealth'] (0,-1.7)--(0,1.8);
\draw[black, thick] (O)--(B);
\draw[gray, thick] (O) circle (1.5);

\draw[red, thick, ->,>=stealth'] (0.3,0) arc(0:150:0.3)  node[above right, xshift=3, midway] {$\theta$};
\draw[blue, ultra thick] (1.5,0) arc(0:150:1.5)  node[above right, midway, yshift=-8] {$t=\dfrac{5\pi}{6}$};
\filldraw[black] (B) circle (.06cm) node[anchor=south east, yshift=-3] { $P\left(\dfrac{-\sqrt{3}}{2}, \dfrac{1}{2}\right)$};
\end{tikzpicture}
}%
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
\par
Thus, the coordinates of \(P\) are \(\left(\dfrac{-\sqrt{3}}{2},\dfrac{1}{2}\right)\), as shown at right.%
\end{example}

\item{}The sine, cosine, or tangent of a particular angle is the same whether the angle is measured in radians or in degrees.%
\item{}You should memorize the trig values of the special angles in radians.%
\begin{sidebyside}{1}{0.175}{0.175}{0}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.65}%
\resizebox{\ifdim\width > \linewidth\linewidth\else\width\fi}{!}{%
{\centering%
{\tabularfont%
\begin{tabular}{AcAcAcAcAcA}\hrulethick
Degrees&Radians&Sine&Cosine&Tangent\tabularnewline\hrulethin
\(0\degree\)&\(0\)&\(0\)&\(1\)&\(0\)\tabularnewline\hrulethin
\(30\degree\)&\(\dfrac{\pi}{6}\)&\(\dfrac{1}{2}\)&\(\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\)&\(\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\)\tabularnewline\hrulethin
\(45\degree\)&\(\dfrac{\pi}{4}\)&\(\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\)&\(\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\)&\(1\)\tabularnewline\hrulethin
\(60\degree\)&\(\dfrac{\pi}{3}\)&\(\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\)&\(\dfrac{1}{2}\)&\(\sqrt{3}\)\tabularnewline\hrulethin
\(90\degree\)&\(\dfrac{\pi}{2}\)&\(1\)&\(0\)&undefined\tabularnewline\hrulethin
\end{tabular}
}%
\par}
}%
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
\item{}To find the sine or cosine of a real number \(t\), we find the sine or cosine of the angle \(\theta = t\) in radians.%
\item{}\begin{assemblage}{Assemblage}{Coordinates on a Unit Circle.}{assemblage-The-Circular-Functions-g-c-b-a-d-a}%
\begin{sidebyside}{2}{0}{0}{0.04}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.5}[center]%
The \terminology{coordinates} of the point \(P\) determined by an arc of length \(t\) in standard position on a unit circle are%
\begin{equation*}
(x, y) = \left(\cos (t), \sin (t)\right)
\end{equation*}
%
\end{sbspanel}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.46}[center]%
\resizebox{\linewidth}{!}{%
\begin{tikzpicture}[scale=.8]       
\coordinate (O) at (0,0);
\coordinate (A) at (0:1.5);
\coordinate (B) at (140:1.5);

\draw[black, thick, ->,>=stealth'] (-1.7,0)--(1.9,0);
\draw[black, thick, ->,>=stealth'] (0,-1.7)--(0,1.9);
\draw[gray, thick] (O) circle (1.5);

\draw[blue, ultra thick] (1.5,0) arc(0:140:1.5)  node[above right, xshift=2, yshift=-2, midway] {$t$};
\filldraw[black] (A) circle (.06cm) node[anchor=north west, yshift=-5] { $(1,0)$};
\filldraw[black] (B) circle (.06cm) node[anchor=south east, xshift=3] { $\left(\cos (t), \sin (t)\right)$};
\end{tikzpicture}
}%
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
\end{assemblage}
%
\item{}\begin{assemblage}{Assemblage}{The Circular Functions.}{assemblage-The-Circular-Functions-g-c-b-a-e-a}%
Let \(P\) be the terminal point of an arc of length \(t\) in standard position on a unit circle. The \terminology{circular functions} of \(t\) are defined by%
\begin{sidebyside}{2}{0}{0}{0}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.65}[center]%
%
\begin{equation*}
\begin{aligned}[t]
\cos (t) \amp = x\\
\sin (t) \amp = y\\
\tan (t) \amp = \dfrac{y}{x},~~x \not= 0\\
\end{aligned}
\end{equation*}
%
\end{sbspanel}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.35}[center]%
\resizebox{\linewidth}{!}{%
\begin{tikzpicture}[scale=.8]
    \coordinate (O) at (0,0);
    \coordinate (A) at (0:1.5);
    \coordinate (B) at (140:1.5);

    \draw[black, thick, ->,>=stealth'] (-1.7,0)--(2,0);
    \draw[black, thick, ->,>=stealth'] (0,-1.7)--(0,1.9);
    \draw[gray, thick] (O) circle (1.5);

    \draw[blue, ultra thick] (1.5,0) arc(0:140:1.5)  node[above right, midway, xshift=3, yshift=-2] {$t$};
    \filldraw[black] (A) circle (.1cm) node[anchor=north west, yshift=-5] { $(1,0)$};
    \filldraw[black] (B) circle (.1cm) node[anchor=south east, yshift=-1] { $(x,y)$};
\end{tikzpicture}
}%
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
\end{assemblage}
%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{subsubsectionptx}

\begin{divisionexercise}{31}{}{}{exercise-hmwk-6-2-exercises-h}%
The sunrise time in Wellington, New Zealand, on the \(n\)th day of the year can be modeled by%
\begin{equation*}
S = 1.93 ~\sin ~(0.016n - 1.13) + 6.14
\end{equation*}
where \(S\) is given in hours after midnight. Find the sunrise time on January 1 (day \(n = 1\)),  April 1 (day \(n = 91\)), July 1 (day \(n = 182\)), and on October 1 (day \(n = 274\)).%
\end{divisionexercise}%
\begin{divisionexercise}{32}{}{}{exercise-hmwk-6-2-exercises-i}%
The variable star RT Cygni reached its maximum magnitude on May 22, 2004, and \(t\) days later its magnitude is given by%
\begin{equation*}
M = 9.55 - 2.25 ~\cos ~(0.033t)
\end{equation*}
Find the magnitude of RT Cygni on days \(t = 0,~ t = 48,~ t = 95,~ t = 142,\) and \(t = 190\). (Note that smaller values of \(M\) denote brighter magnitudes.)%
\end{divisionexercise}%

\begin{divisionexerciseeg}{80}{}{}{exercise-hmwk-6-2-exercises-ab-e}%
One of the most intriguing features of Stonehenge is the position of the four Station Stones.%
\begin{sidebyside}{1}{0.1}{0.1}{0}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.8}%
\includegraphics[width=\linewidth]{external/photos/hp6-2-80a.png}
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
\par
They form the corners of a rectangle inscribed in the Aubrey Circle on the perimeter of the henge, which has diameter 288 feet. A line from the center of the circle and perpendicular to the long edge of the rectangle points through the Slaughter Stones at the entrance of the henge and out to the Heel Stone. If you stood in the center of the circle on the summer solstice, you would see the sun rise directly over the Heel Stone.%
\begin{sidebyside}{1}{0.175}{0.175}{0}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.65}%
\includegraphics[width=\linewidth]{external/photos/hp6-2-80b.png}
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
\par
%
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*]
\item{}The sun rises \(48.6\degree\) east of north on the summer solstice at Stonehenge. If the positive \(y\)-axis points north, find the coordinates of the henge entrance relative to its center.%
\item{}The northernmost station stone is located \(66.6\degree\) of arc counterclockwise from the entrance. Find its coordinates relative to the center of the henge.%
\end{enumerate}
%
\end{divisionexerciseeg}%
\end{exercisegroup}
\par\medskip\noindent
\end{exercises-subsection}

\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Section 6.3 Graphs of the Circular Functions}
\typeout{************************************************}
%
\begin{sectionptx}{Section}{Graphs of the Circular Functions}{}{Graphs of the Circular Functions}{}{}{section-Graphs-of-the-The-Circular-Functions}
\begin{introduction}{}%
We can graph the circular functions \(y =\sin (t),~ y = \cos (t),\) and \(y = \tan (t) ~\) just as we graphed trigonometric functions of angles in degrees. The only difference is that we scale the horizontal axis in radians.%
\end{introduction}%
%
%
\typeout{************************************************}
\typeout{Subsection  The Sine and Cosine Functions}
\typeout{************************************************}
%
\begin{subsectionptx}{Subsection}{The Sine and Cosine Functions}{}{The Sine and Cosine Functions}{}{}{subsection-Graphs-of-the-The-Circular-Functions-c}
Consider the graph shown below.%
\begin{sidebyside}{1}{0.2}{0.2}{0}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.6}%
\resizebox{\linewidth}{!}{%
\begin{tikzpicture}[scale=.8]
\draw[cyan,step=1/2] (0,-2) grid (8,2);
\draw[->,>=stealth'] (0,0) -- (8.3,0) node[right] {$t$};
\draw[->,>=stealth'] (0,-2) -- (0,2.3) node[above] {$y$};

\foreach \x in {1,2, ...,8}
    \draw[black] (\x, .08) --++(0,-.16) node[below, fill=white, inner sep=1, yshift=-2]{$\x$};
\foreach \y in {-1,1}
    \draw[black, thick] (.08,\y ) --++(-.16,0) node[anchor=east] {$\y$};

\draw[domain=0:8,smooth,variable=\x,red,very thick] plot ({\x},{sin(deg(\x))});
\end{tikzpicture}
}%
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
\par
You can probably recognize this graph as one cycle of \(y = \sin (t)\). For example, you can see that the graph completes one cycle at \(t = 2\pi\) radians, or approximately 6.28. It reaches its maximum value, \(y = 1\), at \(t = \dfrac{\pi}{2}\), or approximately 1.57. You should also notice that \(y = 0\) at \(t = \pi\), approximately 3.14.%
\par
Instead of scaling the horizontal axis with integers, we often use multiples of \(\pi\). Using such a scale, we can show the exact location of the intercepts of the graph, and of its high and low points.%
\begin{example}{Example}{}{example-Graphs-of-the-The-Circular-Functions-c-f}%
Graph one cycle of \(y = \sin (t)\), and scale the horizontal axis in multiples of \(\pi\).%
\par\smallskip%
\noindent\textbf{\blocktitlefont Solution}.\hypertarget{solution-Graphs-of-the-The-Circular-Functions-c-f-b}{}\quad{}We start by making a table of values for \(\sin (t)\), where \(t\) is in radians. We'll use the special values of \(t\), because we know the sines of those values.%
\begin{sidebyside}{1}{0.05}{0.05}{0}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.9}%
\resizebox{\ifdim\width > \linewidth\linewidth\else\width\fi}{!}{%
{\centering%
{\tabularfont%
\begin{tabular}{AcAcAcAcAcAcAcAcAcAcA}\hrulethick
\(t\)&\(0\)&\(\dfrac{\pi}{6}\)&\(\dfrac{\pi}{4}\)&\(\dfrac{\pi}{3}\)&\(\dfrac{\pi}{2}\)&\(\dfrac{2\pi}{3}\)&\(\dfrac{3\pi}{4}\)&\(\dfrac{5\pi}{6}\)&\(\pi\)\tabularnewline\hrulethin
\(\sin (t)\)&\(0\)&\(0.500\)&\(0.707\)&\(0.866\)&\(1.000\)&\(0.866\)&\(0.707\)&\(0.500\)&\(0\)\tabularnewline\hrulethin
\end{tabular}
}%
\par}
}%
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
\par
In order to plot the points in the table, we scale the horizontal axis in multiples of \(\dfrac{\pi}{12}\). (Note that the special values are all multiples of \(\dfrac{\pi}{12}\). Thus, \(\dfrac{\pi}{6} = 2\left(\dfrac{\pi}{12}\right)\), \(~ \dfrac{\pi}{4} = 3\left(\dfrac{\pi}{12}\right)\), and so on.)  The table lists values of \(\sin (t)\) in the first two quadrants; in quadrants three and four the sine values are negative.%
\begin{sidebyside}{1}{0.025}{0.025}{0}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.95}%
\resizebox{\ifdim\width > \linewidth\linewidth\else\width\fi}{!}{%
{\centering%
{\tabularfont%
\begin{tabular}{AcAcAcAcAcAcAcAcAcAcA}\hrulethick
\(t\)&\(\pi\)&\(\dfrac{7\pi}{6}\)&\(\dfrac{5\pi}{4}\)&\(\dfrac{4\pi}{3}\)&\(\dfrac{3\pi}{2}\)&\(\dfrac{5\pi}{3}\)&\(\dfrac{7\pi}{4}\)&\(\dfrac{11\pi}{6}\)&\(2\pi\)\tabularnewline\hrulethin
\(\sin (t)\)&\(0\)&\(-0.500\)&\(-0.707\)&\(-0.866\)&\(-1.000\)&\(-0.866\)&\(-0.707\)&\(-0.500\)&\(0\)\tabularnewline\hrulethin
\end{tabular}
}%
\par}
}%
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
\par
The completed graph is shown below.%
\begin{sidebyside}{1}{0.1}{0.1}{0}%
\begin{sbspanel}{0.8}%
\resizebox{\linewidth}{!}{%
\begin{tikzpicture} [scale=1.4]

\draw[cyan,xstep=pi/12, ystep=1/4] (0,-3/2) grid ($2*pi*(1,0)+(0,3/2) $);
\draw[->,>=stealth'] (0,0) -- (6.5,0) node[right] {$t$};
\draw[->,>=stealth'] (0,-1.5) -- (0,1.8) node[above] {$y$};

\foreach \y in {-1, -0.5, 0.5,1}
\draw[black, thick] (.06,\y ) --++(-.12,0) node[anchor=east, xshift=-3, fill=white, inner sep=1pt] {$\y$};

\draw[black, thick] (2*pi,.06) --++(0,-.12) node[anchor=north, xshift=2,yshift=-3, fill=white, inner sep=1pt,] {$2\pi$};

\draw[black, thick] (pi,.06) --++(0,-.12) node[anchor=north, yshift=-2, fill=white, inner sep=1pt] {$\pi$};

\draw[black, thick] (pi,.06) --++(0,-.12) node[anchor=north, yshift=-2, fill=white, inner sep=1pt] {$\pi$};

\draw[black, thick] (pi/2,.06) --++(0,-.12) node[anchor=north, yshift=-2, fill=white, inner sep=1pt] {$\dfrac{\pi}{2}$};
\draw[black, thick] (3*pi/2,.06) --++(0,-.12) node[anchor=north, yshift=-2, fill=white, inner sep=1pt] {$\dfrac{3\pi}{2}$};

\draw[black, thick] (pi/4,.06) --++(0,-.12) node[anchor=north, yshift=-2, fill=white, inner sep=1pt] {$\dfrac{\pi}{4}$};

\draw[black, thick] (3*pi/4,.06) --++(0,-.12) node[anchor=north, yshift=-2, fill=white, inner sep=1pt] {$\dfrac{3\pi}{4}$};
\draw[black, thick] (5*pi/4,.06) --++(0,-.12) node[anchor=north, yshift=-2, fill=white, inner sep=1pt] {$\dfrac{5\pi}{4}$};
\draw[black, thick] (7*pi/4,.06) --++(0,-.12) node[anchor=north, yshift=-2, fill=white, inner sep=1pt] {$\dfrac{7\pi}{4}$};

\draw[domain=0:2*pi,smooth,variable=\x,red,very thick] plot ({\x},{sin(deg(\x))});
\end{tikzpicture}
}%
\end{sbspanel}%
\end{sidebyside}%
\end{example}
If we continued to plot points for values of \(t\) greater than \(2 \pi\) or less than 0, we would see the periodic behavior of the graph, as it repeats the same shape over each interval of length \(2 \pi\), just as it does for periods of \(360\degree\) when the angles are measured in degrees.%
